awd_titl_txt: Reaction rate scaling in porous media in the transport controlled regime
awd_abstract_narration:
This research applies a theory of solute transport in porous media developed by the investigator to predict the time dependence of chemical reaction rates near the earth's surface.  Chemical weathering rates, for example, of silicate minerals, have significant impacts on the global carbon cycle, with implications for climate change, extinctions, and soil production.  It is well known that chemical weathering rates in the earth's crust decrease rapidly with increasing time, diminishing by as much as seven orders of magnitude (a factor of 10 million) as the time scale for observation increases from hours to millions of years. These weathering processes are complex. A full solution would require simultaneous treatment of the chemical equilibration of various compounds on particle surfaces and in solution, the movement of reagents and reaction products through the porous media, and changes in the nature of the particle surfaces.  Researchers apply the greatly simplifying assumption that weathering rates are proportional to solute transport velocities, which they know how to predict.  Without reagents, the reactions do not occur; without removal of the weathering products, reactions reach equilibrium and cease.  As the weathered layer of the surface deepens, the transport paths that bring reacting species together become longer and more tortuous (i.e., they exhibit frequent changes in direction). This research clarifies the degree to which the paths become more tortuous and thus how drastically the reactions are slowed. In addition, it provides insight into how the tortuosity of paths relevant for solute transport can be altered.  

Investigators' results may also applicable to rates of deposition and leaching of toxic chemicals in the subsurface, making them relevant to a wide range of threats to our environment. Nutrient transport in agricultural run-off can be a serious threat to streams, estuaries, and near-shore environments.  On the other hand, efficient nutrient transport in the shallow subsurface enhances the success of industrial agriculture.  Understanding of how to influence the tortuosity of such paths can thus aid in the optimization of agricultural and environmental needs. The present research is relevant not only for solute transport in fluid flow, but also for applications as diverse as cellular mitosis, blood perfusion in the brain, chromatography, filtration, secondary oil recovery, catalysis, the behavior of packed bed reactors, degradation of building materials, tissue physiology, migration and epidemiology, heat dispersion in foams and the internal dynamics of the atom.

Reaction rates on surfaces in porous media decline with time. We proposed that this reduction was often due to the difficulty in getting reagents to, or in removing the products from, the site of the reaction. This is termed transport-limitation of reactions. Contrary to the typical assumption that molecular diffusion was the relevant mechanism for transporting reaction constituents, we assumed that the ability of moving fluid to transport the solutes was most important. The theory of solute transport in moving fluids has until recently mostly been modeled on diffusion, but we used percolation theory to calculate the probability that solutes would travel along different paths through the medium and the time that the transport would take along such paths. Thus, if solute enters a medium uniformly on one side, our result would predict how much solute would subsequently come out on the other side over time. Previous refereed publications had shown that our theoretical treatment was predictive, not just descriptive.

In the present proposal we hypothesized that our calculated solute velocity would be proportional to reaction rates. We verified this by comparison with experiments in nearly a dozen systems, some of which are shown in Figures 1 and 2. We also demonstrated that results obtained for weathering rates of surface rocks over time periods from months to almost ten million years conformed to the prediction (Figure 3). We then reasoned that if the reaction rates were proportional to solute velocities, such quantities as soil depths should be proportional to typical solute transport distances. This prediction was verified by comparing with 29 soils around the world over time intervals from years to 100 million years.

A simple version of the solution to solute transport was then determined to be a scaling law (a power function of time) that related the solute transport time and the time for water to flow through a single pore (1 second) to the solute transport distance and the length of a single pore (about 1 micron). The power law for transport distance then yielded only 100 meters for 100 million years, which is the depth of the oldest "soils" in the world, aluminum-rich laterites of Australia. 

The implication of such slow transport rates is that vegetation, for example, if dependent on such slow solute transport, could not grow at any reasonable rate. The principle adaptation of vegetation for the purpose of accessing necessary nutrients in the soil was then shown to be the dendritic structure of the roots. The advantages of hierarchical searches are well-known, but the roots still grow along tortuous paths that are guided by the optimal water flow paths. Using the optimal path exponent of percolation theory to predict the spatial tortuosity of these paths we predicted a different scaling relationship for natural vegetation growth, which was verified to constrain the maximum plant growth rates over periods from 5 minutes to 100,000 years. The origin of this scaling relationship is also at 1 micron and one second. In addition we determined that the growth rates of the fastest growing trees in the world, Dipterocarps of the tropics, Eucalypts of Australia, and the conifers of the Pacific Northwest, conformed closely to the predictions (shown for the Pacific Northwest conifers in Figure 4 and Figure 5)

Finally, we identified the principle modification of plant growth rates due to human intervention as being a homogeneous delivery of nutrients to the plants at the speed of the water flow through the subsurface. Using here just the typical flow rate in the subsurface it was possible to constrain the maximum crop growth rates over a period from minutes to 1 year.

A simultaneous graph of sol formation rates, natural vegetation growth rates, and crop growth rates, showing their common origin is presented in Figure 6.
